item.title: BMW 320 blue 4 door abandoned vehicle parked on pavement, 4th December
item.description:
Vehicle BMW 320 blue 4 door most likely an abandoned vehicle, car has not moved for months and it looks like the person crashed the car and left it, this is left at the postcode DA16 1SA on Bethel Road at the end of the primary school

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Bethel Road, Welling, Greater London

item.title: A bin has been left here for weeks, and nothing has been done about it, 4th December
item.description:
Someone dumped this bin here several weeks, maybe even months ago. This neighbourhood is deteriorating fast, it’s outrageous. Why are we paying such an expensive council tax??? DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT ASAP. We shouldn’t have to deal with this — your teams ar

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Dawes Street, Walworth, Greater London

item.title: Parked car blocking cycle lane and Resource Centre accessibility, 4th December
item.description:
Cars keep parking at the entrance of the cycle lane (off Bradenham Close) which forces cyclists onto the pavement right in front of The Southwark Resource Centre (10 Bradenham Close, SE17 2QB). This is especially worrying as the centre welcomes people who have mobility issues. The parked cars also block ambulances and special transport buses from accessing the centre safely, which really should be a priority. It seems the only reason these cars stop there is to avoid paying for parking and it is creating problems for both centre users and cyclists.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Boyson Road, Walworth, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: 23 Goodge Street., 4th December
item.description:
Dear Sir/Madam, I am a tenant at 23 Basement, Goodge Street, London W1T 2PL. From January 2020 and for over two and a half years, my shop has been experiencing a persistent leak from the pavement area outside the premises. This has caused property damage and created an unsafe environment for myself, my team, and our clients. Water continues to enter the property, and there is a serious risk that someone may slip and sustain a severe injury. We have been trying our best to manage the situation. However, the leak has now caused the fire alarm system to malfunction. Water has reached the alarm arm in the affected area, leading to electrical issues and a system fuse. I had to call an engineer to repair the damage, and their assessment clearly stated that this issue must be resolved urgently, as it may result in further fire and electrical hazards. My landlord, Mr Pany Economides, has made several attempts to address the problem. His contractor has inspected the site with flood test and advised that the leak is originating from the pavement cracks, where there are visible gaps between service covers for electrical cables and other utilities. I have attached photographs for your reference. At my landlord’s request, I am writing to you to urgently investigate and resolve this matter. As you can imagine, this is a significant health and safety concern, and it is not safe for us to continue working under these conditions. The fire alarm system remains at risk of malfunctioning again, and certain components may need to be temporarily disabled to prevent major system damage. This is especially dangerous as there is a restaurant and three apartments located above my shop. I kindly request urgent action, as I also have a serious medical emergency in my family and may need to travel outside the country. I want to ensure my team is not placed in any avoidable danger during my absence. Best Regards, Vaibhav Malani
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 22, Goodge Street, Fitzrovia, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet
